newsitem.title: TAIWAN: Walesa predicts fall of communism within five years.
newsitem.headline: Walesa predicts fall of communism within five years.

text.p: Ex-president Lech Walesa of Poland brought his anti-communist crusade to Taiwan on Friday, praising its democratic achievements and predicting that communism would perish from the world within five years.
Walesa, on a five-day tour of the island, met Taiwan's democratic pioneer, President Lee Teng-hui, on Friday and said "freedom and democracy ultimately will annihilate communism".
"It is a behaviour contrary to the world trend," Walesa was quoted by Lee's office as saying. "Communism will be replaced completely by freedom and democracy within five years."
Walesa won the 1993 Nobel peace prize for leading the Polish Solidarity union's peaceful struggle for democracy, which ended with the downfall of Poland's communist government.
Walesa was elected president in 1990 but unseated in 1995 by Aleksander Kwasniewski.

Lee, who in March became the first directly elected president in Chinese history, is widely credited with transforming the island from an authoritarian regime to a democracy that culminated with the March elections.
The elections drew the ire of Taipei's communist rival in China, which has seen Taiwan as a renegade province since a civil war split them in 1949.
Beijing launched menacing war games near the island prior to the elections as a warning against any moves away from Taiwan's eventual reunification with the mainland.
In his meeting with Walesa, Lee reiterated the desire of his exiled Republic of China government to reunite with China, but insisted democratic reforms on the mainland must come first.
"Although communist China seeks economic reform and liberalisation, it is still very conservative politically, and would not give freedom and democracy to its people," Lee said.
China on Wednesday sentenced democracy advocate Wang Dan to 11 years in prison for plotting to subvert the government, triggering condemnation from many countries.
Walesa urged Lee to "inform world leaders of the struggle of the Republic of China and the hard work it has put in to fight against communism", Lee's office said.
